name: Tirumala Venkateswara Temple
dressCode: Traditional attire. Men: Dhoti or pants. Women: Saree or salwar. No shorts or sleeveless.
history: One of the richest and most visited temples in the world. The deity is believed to be a form of Vishnu. The temple has been patronized by various dynasties over centuries.
visitorGuidelines: Book online darshan. No phones inside. Free darshan queue can be long; special entry tickets available.

name: Kashi Vishwanath Temple
dressCode: Modest traditional wear. Remove footwear before entering.
history: One of the twelve Jyotirlingas. The city of Varanasi is considered one of the oldest living cities. The current structure was built by Ahilyabai Holkar in 1780.
visitorGuidelines: Strict security. No bags or phones. Lockers available.

name: Golden Temple (Harmandir Sahib)
dressCode: Cover head (scarf provided). Remove shoes. Modest clothing.
history: Built in the 16th century. The holiest Gurudwara for Sikhs. Open to all religions. Surrounded by Amrit Sarovar (pool of nectar).
visitorGuidelines: Head must be covered. Free langar for all. No alcohol or tobacco. Photography allowed in outer areas.

name: Jama Masjid, Delhi
timings: 7:00 AM - 12:00 PM, 1:30 PM - 6:30 PM (closed during Namaz)
dressCode: Modest clothing required. Women must cover head. Robes available at entrance.
history: Built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan between 1644-1656. One of the largest mosques in India, accommodating 25,000 worshippers. Made of red sandstone and white marble.
visitorGuidelines: Remove shoes. Modest dress required. Photography may require a fee. Closed during prayer times.

name: Haji Ali Dargah
deity: Sufi Saint Haji Ali Shah Bukhari
dressCode: Modest clothing. Cover head. Remove shoes at entrance.
history: Built in 1431 in memory of Haji Ali Shah Bukhari. Located on an islet 500 meters off the coast, connected by a causeway that submerges during high tide.
visitorGuidelines: Check tide timings. Open to all faiths. No photography near the tomb. Cover head with cloth.

name: Basilica of Bom Jesus
dressCode: Modest clothing. No shorts or sleeveless. Respectful attire.
rituals: Exposition of St. Francis Xavier's relics
history: UNESCO World Heritage Site. Built in 1594-1605. Houses the mortal remains of St. Francis Xavier. Finest example of Baroque architecture in India.
bestTimeToVisit: November to February; December 3 for the Feast
visitorGuidelines: No flash photography. Maintain silence. Follow Mass etiquette. Open to all.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Good Health
history: Known as the 'Lourdes of the East'. Famous for miraculous healings. Annual feast in September attracts millions of pilgrims of all faiths.
bestTimeToVisit: August-September for Feast; October-March for weather
visitorGuidelines: Open to all religions. Large crowds during feast. Book accommodation early.
wikiTitle: Basilica of Our Lady of Good Health, Velankanni

name: Mahabodhi Temple
dressCode: Modest, respectful clothing. Remove shoes inside.
history: UNESCO World Heritage Site. Marks the spot where Siddhartha Gautama attained enlightenment under the Bodhi tree. One of the most sacred Buddhist sites in the world.
visitorGuidelines: Silence in meditation areas. No touching the Bodhi tree. Respectful behavior required.

name: Dilwara Jain Temples
dressCode: Modest clothing. No leather items. Remove shoes.
history: Built between the 11th and 13th centuries. Famous for extraordinary marble carvings considered among the finest in the world. Five temples dedicated to different Tirthankaras.
visitorGuidelines: No leather items allowed. Photography prohibited inside. No food or drinks.

name: Meenakshi Amman Temple
dressCode: Traditional. No shorts or revealing clothes.
history: Historic temple complex with 14 gopurams. Dedicated to Meenakshi (Parvati) and Sundareswarar (Shiva). Dates back over 2000 years.
visitorGuidelines: Free darshan. No phones in sanctum. Photography restricted in inner areas.

name: Somnath Temple
history: First among the twelve Jyotirlingas. Rebuilt several times after invasions. Current structure built in 1951.
visitorGuidelines: Security check. Dress modestly. Photography allowed in designated areas.

name: Jagannath Temple, Puri
history: One of the Char Dham. Famous for Rath Yatra. Deities are made of wood and replaced in a special ritual.
bestTimeToVisit: October to February; June-July for Rath Yatra
visitorGuidelines: Dress code strictly enforced. Book darshan online during peak season.
